name: Matrix 07/12/2025 14:04:43 - lakh
observation_report:
SECTION 1 – SITE ARRIVAL AND INDUCTION
1.

fdsgdfgfdgdf. I arrived to the project on agreed time, weather sunny. I met Ivan at the gate where he followed security rules by signing in and passing fenced access. He already wore full PPE: high-viz, hard hat, gloves, boots and glasses. Ivan showed me fire point and health & safety board.
AC covered: 
                641:1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 2.1, 4.1; 642:1.1
Image suggestion: learner signing in and wearing PPE.

{{Site_arrival_and_induction_table}}

2.

Inside the induction room Ivan displayed CSCS card, signed RAMS and daily sheet. I observed learner storing PPE and small tools correctly in tool bag.
AC covered: 
                641:5.1; 642:1.1, 4.1
Image suggestion: induction paperwork and CSCS verification.

{{Site_arrival_and_induction_table}}

SECTION 2 – HEALTH, SAFETY AND WELFARE
3.

On way to work area Ivan spotted wires loose on floor. He reported hazard to site manager. He told me trips can injure people and damage tools.
AC covered: 
                641:2.1, 3.1, 3.3, 3.4, 3.5
Image suggestion: staged hazard reporting example.

{{Health_safety_and_welfare_table}}

4.

Ivan checked podium and hop-up before start. We discussed emergency actions and he explained he must raise alarm, go assembly point and call supervisor if safe.
AC covered: 
                641:3.2, 4.1; 643:1.1
Image suggestion: inspection of hop-up platform.

{{Health_safety_and_welfare_table}}

SECTION 3 – COMMUNICATION AND WORK COORDINATION
5.

I observed Ivan speaking politely to supervisor and colleagues, confirming work sequence and access needs. He applied equality and respect to all.
AC covered: 
                642:3.1, 4.1
Image suggestion: learner communicating with supervisor.

{{Communication_and_work_coordination_table}}

SECTION 4 – RESOURCE HANDLING, MOVEMENT AND STORAGE
6.

Ivan cleaned work zone, disposed waste in bags, stored hop-up, podium, screw gun and multi-tool into toolbox. He handled plasterboards safely with a colleague to avoid strain.
AC covered: 
                643:3.1, 3.2, 3.3, 4.1, 5.1, 5.2, 7.1, 7.2
Image suggestion: safe lifting technique for plasterboard.

{{Resource_handling_and_storage_table}}

SECTION 5 – INSTALLATION OF DRYLINING SYSTEMS
7.

I observed Ivan installing metal stud partition: measuring, marking, fixing track, positioning studs and securing them. He followed drawings and RAMS.
AC covered: 
                129v4:1.1, 1.2, 3.1, 3.2, 4.1; 642:2.1
Image suggestion: learner fixing metal studs.

{{Installation_of_drylining_systems_table}}

8.

I asked about furring ceilings, lining systems and encasements. Ivan explained he done MF ceiling on office refurb, lining on hotel corridor, and fire encasement on commercial job. He told me typical sequence: hangers, channels, levelling, boarding.
AC covered: 
                129v4:5.1, 5.2, 5.3; 643:1.2
Image suggestion: MF ceiling installation diagram.

{{Installation_of_drylining_systems_table}}

9.

I watched Ivan working on walls over 3m using podium safely. He explained he previously built twin walls, staggered studs, curved walls and service shafts on retail and accommodation projects.
AC covered: 
                129v4:6.1, 7.1, 7.2, 7.3, 7.4; 130v3:6.1, 7.1
Image suggestion: learner using podium safely.

{{Installation_of_drylining_systems_table}}

SECTION 6 – PLASTERBOARD FIXING
10.

I observed plasterboard fixing to metal studs. Ivan measured, cut, aligned and screwed boards with correct spacing and formed opening.
AC covered: 
                130v3:1.1, 1.2, 3.1, 3.2, 4.1
Image suggestion: correct screw pattern on plasterboard.

{{Plasterboard_fixing_table}}

11.

I asked learner about direct bonding. Ivan replied he done dot and dab many times on refurb walls, placing adhesive dabs around perimeter and centre for strong hold.
AC covered: 
                130v3:5.1, 5.2, 5.3
Image suggestion: dot-and-dab alignment example.

{{Plasterboard_fixing_table}}

SECTION 7 – WORKING AT HEIGHT
12.

Ivan worked safely on hop-up and podium, locking equipment and avoiding overreaching. He stepped down to reposition tool or board.
AC covered: 
                641:3.2; 129v4:6.1; 130v3:6.1
Image suggestion: safe podium use.

{{Working_at_height_table}}

SECTION 8 – HOUSEKEEPING AND WASTE DISPOSAL
13.

Ivan maintained good housekeeping, removing waste and storing tools safe. His area was tidy with no obstruction.
AC covered: 
                641:3.2; 642:4.2; 643:5.3
Image suggestion: tidy workplace with waste bags.

{{Housekeeping_and_waste_disposal_table}}

SECTION 9 – COMPLETION OF WORK AND HANDOVER
14.

Learner finished work on time, sent progress photos to supervisor and coordinated with other trades to avoid clash.
AC covered: 
                642:2.2, 3.1, 4.1; 129v4:5.1
Image suggestion: screenshot showing completion evidence.

{{Completion_of_work_and_handover_table}}

SECTION 10 – WELFARE AND END-OF-SHIFT ACTIVITIES
15.

At shift end we visited welfare area. I observed Ivan cleaning the table and keeping area tidy. We reviewed evidence and discussed knowledge questions he still needs to complete.
AC covered: 
                641:3.2; 642:1.1; 643:7.2
Image suggestion: clean welfare table area.

{{Welfare_and_end_of_shift_activities_table}}
